title: Conservation Practices Commonly Used in Animal Agriculture

tasks.task: Farmer and rancher activities in managing agricultural systems and natural resources.
subtasks: Implementing NRCS conservation practices.
Coordinating efforts with EPA and state/local governments for compliance and funding.
Protecting natural resources through manure management (e.g., diversions, storage).
Nutrient management planning and application.
Land and pasture management (e.g., prescribed grazing).
Managing animal mortalities (e.g., proper disposal, pathogen control).
Understanding Clean Water and Clean Air Act requirements.
Adhering to federal and state regulations.
Developing a Comprehensive Nutrient Management Plan (CNMP).
Documenting manure storage and application practices.
Using field mapping for precise nutrient application.
Installing buffers or filter strips at field edges.
Implementing windbreaks around livestock areas.
Composting manure.
Employing solid-liquid separation techniques.
Directing water away from production areas with diversions, roofs, gutters.
Filtering manure to reduce moisture content and volume.
Rotational grazing to maintain vegetation and soil health.
Fencing livestock to prevent water contamination.
Preventing overland flow of manure-laden water.
Managing nutrients during high-risk times (saturated soils, frozen conditions).
Properly managing dead animals to avoid resource contamination.
Controlling odors from livestock to prevent air quality issues.
